1253311.content:
Friday night, you and your best friend Juan meet outside the small local nightclub to shoot some pool. You both decided on coming early because the club gets packed pretty quickly on Fridays, and the only pool table there will undoubtedly be hogged by some random group of thugs who don't know the meaning of time limit.

You and Juan go inside and rush anxiously and excitedly to the billiard room. You step through the doorless entryway, into the dimly lit billiard room, only to find that the table is in use. However, it's not the typical group of scruff men with facial hair and thick, gaudy tattoos; rather, it's four young-looking guys in their twenties; they're clean-shaven, have buzz cuts, and wear identical white tank tops that expose either a couple sparse, tasteful tattoos or none at all.

"Aw, great," Juan grumbles, and he droops like a wilted flower.

"Yeah, it sucks, but how were we supposed to know?"

Juan pouts.

"Ask them when they'll be done. They seem like good-looking guys—err, I mean, nice . . . they seem like nice guys. Yeah, Juan, go ask."

Every time you get tongue-tied in front of him, you're afraid he's going to find out. Luckily, he's totally oblivious to such things, despite being a major homophobe (ironic, isn't it?).

"You ask," Juan mutters.

You look at the four cute guys and hesitate. Your breathing suddenly gets heavy when you notice the one with the muscles. It would be a dream to have a friend like that who could be your personal bodyguard, one who also happened to have a stunning, chiselled, perfectly smooth baby (yet also manly) face; buzz cut dark brown hair, which he probably shaves himself since he obviously takes good care of his appearance; and a body that speaks for itself—even if he were wearing a black t-shirt, the way his body would fill and shape it would say it all.

"Well?!" Juan elbows you in the ribs impatiently.

"Aaahaha. Don't! Not now, I mean."

"Well then, go ask them!" He frowns at you, then scowls at the four identically-dressed boys.

You take a deep breath and walk up to one of the more slender guys. The muscular one is lining up a shot, but when he sees you, he freezes in that pose and looks up at you.

"Uh, um . . . ummm." Your heart pounds as you fixate on the boy with the long stick.

"Can I help you," he asks, still holding the pose.

"Um, n–n–no, s–ssssorry, sorry."

You slink back to Juan and continue walking toward the open entryway.

"Hey, bro!" a deep, yet boyish, voice calls.

You turn. The hot guy stands at the pool table and leans on the pool cue in front of him. Juan gives you a nervous glance and comes and stands next to you for support—or to make a quick getaway, you're not exactly sure which.

"W–what?"

The boy still doesn't smile, nor does he frown or scowl; he just looks—intense. "Did I say you had to go?"

You twitch your head left and right as though you had tremors.

"Well, then." He looks and points his stick at one of the wooden chairs strewn about the room. Then he glances back at you and resumes taking his shot.

"This reeks, I'm going home," Juan whines. "You coming?"
1253311.title: Huntley Ritter

He clutches your forearms and tries to pull them off, but tickling always makes him weak. You walk into him, still kneading the base of his neck, and back him out of the games room, into the empty bar. He squeals nonstop and sounds like a cross between a baby and a mouse.

You stare at him, at his face, and try to remember where you've seen him. "Oh my god. Are you actually, in real life, Huntley R–r–r–r–r—"

"Ritter, yes. What's it to you?" His expression softens up, and he almost smiles. You're in heaven.

"Nothing, sir. Nothing. It's nothing, really. Nothing. It's—"

"Nothing. Got it." He smirks, keeping his eyes on you intently. You feel weak.

"Then how do you know his name?"

You begin to stutter again, and Huntley interrupts, "Is this curious little guy your friend?"

"Y–yeah, so?"

He walks menacingly slowly toward you both. "You like tickling your friends too?"

You feel blood gush into your dick.

"Let's go," Juan insists and yanks on your arm. You're completely stiff. Huntley gets closer.

"Now!" Juan cries, and using both arms he pulls you with him as he scoots to the door.

"Hey, wait a minute, dudes, I want to give you something!"

You stop at the exit and turn. "Y–yes, Huntley Ritter?"

Juan opens the door and drags you out on your heels.

"I'm going to spend some time on the dance floor." Lying is the one thing you hate doing to Juan.

"I feel bad. Do you really want me to stay?"

"I just don't want to feel like I wasted my time and then go home and sulk about it like someone I know."

He grins.

"Stay. We can make our own fun, right?"

"Well, that's what friends do," Juan replies.

You lead him up to the billiard room and stand before the opening. Since the empty bar is so dimly lit, the players don't take notice of you.

"Juan, I have an idea," you whisper, covering the side of your mouth with your hand.

"What?" he replies in a hoarse and muted voice and giggles softly.

You haven't talked like this since you were kids playing army soldiers on the battlefield.

"Tickle them," you reply back.

"Are you crazy?"

"I'll take the guy holding the cue. You go for the leader."

"You're still crazy."

"No, it'll work."

Really, you just want to see Juan get tickled by a muscular guy.

"You take the leader. I'll watch," Juan says.

You snap Juan's hand over his mouth and hold it there while you clutch the back of his neck and deliver ticklish squeezes. Juan shuts his eyes tightly and squirms, and he tries to drop to the ground. You tickle him all the way down until he's flat on his back. Quickly, you mount his stomach and grab his arms, and you force them over his head and pin them to the ground.

Juan rolls his eyes with an annoyed smirk, but doesn't struggle. This isn't the first time you've pinned him like this, and he knows by now he can't do a thing.

You both step out of the games room, into the empty bar, and walk towards the exit. It hurts to think about leaving after you just met this guy and his cronies. You may never see them again. It's not fair.

"Hey, are you okay?" Juan asks.

"Of course I'm okay! Why . . ." You look down and mutter, "Why wouldn't I be?"

Juan squints at you for a moment, then his face changes, and he smiles. He looks at your chest, then opens his arms and spontaneously hugs and squeezes you. He takes a long whiff of your shirt.

"Mmmmmm. Hold me," he says and tucks his head into the crook of your neck, giving you chills. You get nervous whenever he pretends like this; you like it, but you never know how to respond.

You give in to the sudden good feelings and run your hands through his hair. You get a happy twitch in your pants, which worries you, so you mess up his hair and trust that will end the confrontation—before he suspects something (or gets poked).

Juan giggles. "Damn!"

He lets go and compulsively fixes his hair. "Okay, I'm ready, let's go," he says as if nothing ever happened.

"Wait, don't you want to . . . you know . . ." You look toward the doors to the main dance floor and move your shoulders in time with the music.

"You know I don't dance. Tonight sucked, I just want to go home. And I'm sorry I'm in such a bad mood. It's not your fault."

Juan offers you a handshake. You grab his wrist and pull him in, and in a singsong voice, you say, "Someone needs a tickle-hug," singing the last word in a higher pitch as you always do.

"No, not right NOOOOOOOOOOOW–AHAHAHAHA! OKAY, OKAY–HAHAHAHAHA! OKAAAAAAA–HAHAHA–HAAAAAY! PLEA–HEHEHE–HEASE, NOT IN HERE! HAHAHAHA!"
